titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania LJS 457: Loyca parva ... etc.

notesStmt.note: Title for manuscript from closing rubric of predominant work (f. 87r).

msContents.summary: Work on scholastic logic used in universities in the late 15th century, followed by a brief logical work by Paolo della Pergola, a student of Paolo Veneto.

msItem.title: Tractatus de sensu composito et diviso, f. 87r

supportDesc.extent: 90 leaves : 224 x 152 (170 x 100) mm. bound to 230 x 170 mm

collation.p: Paper, i (late 16th- or early 17th-century) + 90 + i (late 16th- or early 17th-century); 1-9¹⁰; [1-90], modern foliation in pencil, lower right recto. Vertical catchwords on last verso of each gathering, lower right verso.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in humanistic cursive script by Franciscus Alexandrus de Callio, another member of the community of Hermits of Saint Augustine in Perugia (f. 87r).

decoDesc.decoNote: 5-line initial in pink, black, green, and gold, with extensions of acanthus leaves, flowers, and gold bezants (f. 1r); pen-and-wash diagram of logical relationships (f. 3v); pen-and-wash diagram in the form of a Porphyrian tree showing a progression from substantia to homo (f. 7v); 2 3-line initials in red at the beginning of the second work (f. 87r); many spaces left empty throughout, with guide letters, for 2-line initials; rubrication and paragraph marks in both text and margins in faint red ink; occasional manicules (for example, f. 22r).

binding.p: Late 16th or early 17th-century parchment; leather spine label, Tract[atus] de comp[osito] et divis[o]; arms of Pope Gregory XIII and Jesuit monogram stamped on spine in black ink.

origin.p: Written in the abbey of the Hermits of Saint Augustine in Perugia in 1475 (f. 87r).

history.provenance: Formerly in the library of the Pontificio Collegio germanico ungarico in Rome (inscription, f. 1r).
Sold by Les Enluminures (Paris and Chicago) to Lawrence J. Schoenberg, Oct. 2003.
Deposit by Lawrence J. Schoenberg and Barbara Brizdle, 2012.
